{{Short description|American actor (1940–2012)}} {{other people}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2019}} {{Infobox person |name = Richard Lynch |image = Richard_Lynch.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Richard Hugh Lynch |birth_date = {{birth date|1940|2|12|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], New York City, U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|2012|6|19|1940|2|12|mf=y}} |death_place = [[Yucca Valley, California]], U.S. |alma_mater = [[The Actors Studio]],
[[HB Studio]] |occupation = Actor |years_active = 1967–2012 |other_names = Richard H. Lynch |spouse = Béatrix Lynch (divorced)
Lily Lynch |children = 1 |relatives = [[Barry Lynch]] (brother) |awards = [[Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actor]] (1982)}} '''Richard Lynch''' (February 12, 1940 – June 19, 2012) was an American actor best known for portraying [[villain]]s in films and television. His film credits included ''[[The Sword and the Sorcerer]]'', ''[[Invasion U.S.A. (1985 film)|Invasion USA]]'', ''[[The Seven-Ups]]'', ''[[Scarecrow (1973 film)|Scarecrow]]'', ''[[Little Nikita]]'', ''[[Bad Dreams (film)|Bad Dreams]]'', ''[[God Told Me To]]'', and ''[[Halloween (2007 film)|Halloween]]''. He appeared in science fiction productions, including ''[[Battlestar Galactica (1978 TV series)|Battlestar Galactica]]'' (as Wolfe) and its sequel series ''[[Galactica 1980]]'' (as Commander Xaviar). He also appeared in such shows as ''[[Starsky and Hutch]]'', ''[[Baretta]]'', ''[[T. J. Hooker]]'', ''[[Blue Thunder (TV series)|Blue Thunder]]'', ''[[Airwolf]]'', ''[[The A-Team]]'', ''[[The Fall Guy]]'', ''[[Charmed]]'', ''[[Vega$]]'', ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'', and ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]''. ==Early life and career== Richard Hugh Lynch was born on February 12, 1940{{cite web | title = PASSINGS: Richard Lynch | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-passings-20120626,0,4088579.story | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = June 27, 2012 | access-date = August 25, 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120711205521/http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-passings-20120626,0,4088579.story | archive-date = July 11, 2012 | url-status = live }}{{cite web|title=Richard Lynch obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/latimes/obituary.aspx?pid=158165634|work=Legacy.com|publisher=Los Angeles Times|access-date=August 25, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203015304/http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/latimes/obituary.aspx?pid=158165634|archive-date=December 3, 2013|url-status=live}} (sometimes incorrectly cited as 1936) in [[Brooklyn]], New York City to Catholic parents of Irish descent. Richard Lynch served in the [[United States Marine Corps]] for four years. Lynch's distinct scarred appearance made him a popular nemesis, and he can be seen in more than 160 film and television performances. The scars came from a 1967 incident in New York's [[Central Park]] in which, under the influence of drugs, he set himself on fire, burning more than 70% of his body.{{cite news|title=Lynch Got Second Chance|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_gAsAAAAIBAJ&pg=2495,2878632&dq=richard-lynch+actor&hl=en|newspaper=Times Daily (Florence, Alabama)|date=March 17, 1971|access-date=June 20, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507054400/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_gAsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3McEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2495,2878632&dq=richard-lynch+actor&hl=en|archive-date=May 7, 2016|url-status=live}} He spent a year in recovery, gave up drug use and ultimately began training at [[The Actors Studio]] and at the [[HB Studio]]. In 1970, he co-starred with [[Robert De Niro]], [[Sally Kirkland]] and [[Diane Ladd]] in the short-lived off-Broadway play ''One Night Stands of a Noisy Passenger,'' written by [[Shelley Winters]].{{Cite web|url=http://iobdb.com/Production/5407|title=One Night Stands of a Noisy Passenger - Lortel Archives|website=iobdb.com|access-date=July 22, 2019}} He often played a villain in features, including ''[[Scarecrow (1973 film)|Scarecrow]]'', which marked his film debut, ''[[The Seven-Ups]]'', ''[[Bad Dreams (film)|Bad Dreams]]'', ''[[The Sword and the Sorcerer]]'', and ''[[Little Nikita]]''. In 1982, Lynch won a [[Saturn Award]] for Best Supporting Actor for his performance as the evil King Cromwell in ''[[The Sword and the Sorcerer]]''.{{Cite web | url = http://www.saturnawards.org/past.html#filmsuportactror | title = Past Saturn Awards | website = [[Saturn Award]]s | via = www.saturnawards.org | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100209012608/http://www.saturnawards.org/past.html | archive-date = 2010-02-09 | access-date = February 5, 2008}} Although Richard Lynch is best known for playing villains, he was cast as the president of the United States in the 2007 film ''[[Mil Mascaras vs. the Aztec Mummy]]''.{{Cite web | url = https://www.popmatters.com/mil-mascaras-resurrection-2496110479.html | title = Mil Mascaras: Resurrection (2007) | last = Gibron | first = Bill | date = October 23, 2008 | website = [[PopMatters]] | access-date = July 22, 2019}}{{cite web | url = http://www.mjsimpson.co.uk/reviews/milmascarasresurrection.html | title = Mil Mascaras: Resurrection | last = Simpson | first = MJ | website = MJSimpson.co.uk | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090123115026/http://www.mjsimpson.co.uk/reviews/milmascarasresurrection.html | archive-date = 2009-01-23 | url-status = usurped}} Lynch starred alongside [[Judson Scott]] in the 1982 short-lived science fiction TV series ''[[The Phoenix (1982 TV series)|The Phoenix]]''. In addition to acting, Lynch was a musician, and he played the saxophone, guitar, piano, and flute. He held Irish citizenship through his Irish-born parents and was a frequent visitor to Ireland. He starred together with brother Barry in the films ''Nightforce'' and ''Total Force''. Lynch's wife Lily starred with him in the film ''Breaking the Silence'' (1998) and son Christopher Lynch appeared with him in the science fiction film ''[[Trancers II]]''. In 1977, Richard Lynch shared the stage with actor Al Pacino, a close friend, in the Broadway play ''The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel.'' Lynch played a Vietnam veteran who used a wheelchair, and was nominated for a Tony in 1977. Through the years, Lynch worked with friend and colleague [[Don Calfa]] in the films ''Necronomicon'' (1993), ''Toughguy'' (1995), ''[[Corpses Are Forever]]'' (2003), and ''Lewisburg'' (2009). ==Later life and death== Lynch married twice — once to Béatrix Lynch (their son Christopher died in 2005 from [[pneumonia]]), and later to Lily Lynch.{{Cite magazine | url = https://variety.com/2012/film/news/actor-richard-lynch-dies-at-76-1118055789/ | title = Actor Richard Lynch dies at 76 | agency = [[Associated Press]] | date = June 20, 2012 | magazine = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | access-date = July 22, 2019 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180714150851/https://variety.com/2012/film/news/actor-richard-lynch-dies-at-76-1118055789/ | archive-date = July 14, 2018 | url-status = live }} Lynch's body was found in his home in [[Yucca Valley, California]] on June 19, 2012. It is not known if Lynch died on June 18 or June 19. After not having heard from Lynch for several days, friend and actress Carol Vogel went to his home to find the door open and his body in his kitchen.{{cite web |title="Halloween" actor Richard Lynch dies aged 76 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/entertainment-us-richardlynch-idUSBRE85K00A20120621 |website=Reuters |date=21 June 2012}}{{cite web |title=Actor Richard Lynch dies at 76 |url=https://variety.com/2012/film/news/actor-richard-lynch-dies-at-76-1118055789/ |website=Variety |date=June 20, 2012}} The cause of death was given as a heart attack. He was survived by his brother Barry and two sisters, Carole Taylor and Cathy Jones. Some news reports following his death incorrectly identified his birth year as 1936, but the obituary in the ''Los Angeles Times'' published by his family correctly listed the year as 1940. ==Filmography== ===Films=== * 1973 ''[[Scarecrow (1973 film)|Scarecrow]]'' as Riley * 1973 ''[[The Seven-Ups]]'' as Moon * 1974 ''[[Open Season (1974 film)|Open Season]]'' as Art {{cite web| title = Richard Lynch (1940-2012)| url = https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0528433/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t4| website = IMDB| date = 1990–2023| access-date = 26 November 2023}} * 1975 ''[[The Happy Hooker (film)|The Happy Hooker]]'' as The Cop * 1976 ''[[The Premonition (1976 film)|The Premonition]]'' as Jude * 1976 ''[[God Told Me To]]'' as Bernard Phillips * 1977 ''The Baron'' as Joey * 1977 ''[[Stunts (film)|Stunts]]'' as Pete Lustig * 1978 ''[[Deathsport]]'' as Ankar Moor * 1979 ''[[Steel (1979 film)|Steel]]'' as Dancer * 1979 ''Delta Fox'' as David 'Delta' Fox * 1979 ''[[Vampire (1979 film)|Vampire]]'' as Prince Anton Voytek * 1980 ''[[The Ninth Configuration]]'' as Richard, 2nd Cyclist * 1980 ''[[The Formula (1980 film)|The Formula]]'' as General Helmut Kladen / Frank Tedesco * 1981 ''[[Sizzle (1981 film)|Sizzle]]'' as Johnny O'Brien * 1982 ''[[The Sword and the Sorcerer]]'' as Titus Cromwell * 1984 ''[[Treasure: In Search of the Golden Horse]]'' as Narrator (voice) * 1985 ''[[Cut and Run (film)|Cut and Run]]'' as Colonel Brian Horne * 1985 ''[[Invasion U.S.A. '''Richard Lynch''' (born December 5, 1962, in [[Lebanon, Ohio]]) is an American [[country music|country]] music singer/[[songwriter]] with a successful career that has lasted over three decades. Lynch’s highest-charting single “A Better Place” topped the [[New Music Weekly]] AM/FM country chart,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stabile|first1=Ryan|title=Independent Country Music Hall of Famer Richard Lynch tops national AM/FM chart|url=https://www.axs.com/independent-country-music-hall-of-famer-richard-lynch-tops-national-am-102806|website=AXS|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Country Music would be "A Better Place" with artists like Richard Lynch|url=https://musicmattersmagazine.com/2016/07/16/country-music-would-be-a-better-place-with-artists-like-richard-lynch/|website=Music Matters Magazine|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> the IndieWorld Country Record Report and spent 32 weeks on top of the [[American folk music|Roots Music]] Report True Country chart. Lynch is a member of the Independent Country Music Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hot Damn! Richard Lynch Talks Traditional Country, Kentucky, And Cinnamon Scnapps|url=http://nodepression.com/interview/hot-damn-richard-lynch-talks-traditional-country-kentucky-and-cinnamon-scnapps|website=No Depression - The Journal of Roots Music|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>

==Life and career==

Lynch was born in [[Lebanon, Ohio]], and raised on a 110-acre farm<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Lynch – She’s Got Me Drinking Again|url=https://www.musicrow.com/2014/06/richard-lynch-shes-got-me-drinking-again/|website=Music Row|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> that his family operated. From his father Woody Lynch,<ref>{{cite news|title=Woody Lynch joned his son Richard Lynch and the Renegade Band for a few songs|publisher=The Jackson County Sun (newspaper)|date=28 May 1992}}</ref> an established local musician, Richard inherited the love for country music and lifestyle.<ref>{{cite web|title=Keeping Tradition Alive: Get to Know Richard Lynch|url=http://thedailycountry.com/interviews/keeping-tradition-alive-get-to-know-richard-lynch|website=The Daily Country|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=An Interview With Country Singer Richard Lynch|url=https://elizagalesinterviews.com/2017/01/02/an-interview-with-country-singer-richard-lynch/|website=Eliza Gales Interviews|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> At the age of 13 Richard picked up the guitar and learned to play. By the age of 15 he got his first gig at a wedding reception. At the age of 18<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mason|first1=Will|title=Keeping Active on the Road As Well As At Home|volume=1|issue=6|publisher=OKI Country Music News|date=January 1994}}</ref> he organized his own band (the Renegade Band<ref>{{cite web|title=About Richard Lynch Band|url=https://www.gigsalad.com/richard_lynch_band_waynesville|website=Gig Salad|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> later renamed the Richard Lynch Band) and has been successfully recording and touring ever since.

Lynch refers to his music as "pure country, showcasing elements of western swing, honky tonk and outlaw country".<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Lynch's bio|url=https://www.gigmasters.com/country-band/richard-lynch-band|website=Official website of Richard Lynch|accessdate=2 April 2017}}</ref> His style is influenced by classic American country artists like [[Keith Whitley]], [[Conway Twitty]] and [[George Strait]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Lucky 13 with Richard Lynch|url=http://www.nashvillemusicguide.com/lucky-13-with-richard-lynch/|website=Nashville Music Guide|accessdate=2 April 2017}}</ref>

In January 2017 Lynch collaborated with [[Ronnie McDowell]] on a military tribute duet "Love Tattoo".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stover|first1=Michael|title=Richard Lynch & Ronnie McDowell Release Military Tribute Single And Video, "Love Tattoo"|url=http://www.groundreport.com/richard-lynch-ronnie-mcdowell-release-military-tribute-single-video-love-tattoo/|website=Ground Report|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jamm|first1=Rick|title=Richard Lynch and Ronnie McDowell: "Love Tattoo" – a military tribute duet|url=http://jamsphere.com/newreleases/richard-lynch-and-ronnie-mcdowell-love-tattoo-a-military-tribute-duet|website=JamSphere|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>

On April 1, 2017, Lynch's third studio album "Mending Fences" was released via an independent record label, Fence Row Records<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Lynch Mending Fences CD Release Party and Benefit Concert|url=https://www.daytonlocal.com/events/richard-lynch-mending-fences-cd-release-party-and-benefit-concert.asp|website=Dayton Local|accessdate=2 April 2017}}</ref> The album features a duet with a bluegrass singer [[Rhonda Vincent]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Papadatos|first1=Marcos|title=Review: Richard Lynch back with new country single 'Cut And Paste' |url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/music/review-richard-lynch-back-with-new-country-single-cut-and-paste/article/489310|website=Digital Journal|accessdate=2 April 2017}}</ref>

Lynch co-hosts “Traditionally Lynch” show on Renegade Radio [[Nashville]].

Lynch is also an accomplished designer and builder of barns.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tee|first1=Robbie|title=Richard Lynch: "A Better Place" is contemporary Country music at its finest!|url=http://jamsphere.com/reviews/richard-lynch-a-better-place-is-contemporary-country-music-at-its-finest|website=JamSphere|accessdate=2 April 2017}}</ref> He resides in [[Waynesville, Ohio]], with his wife Donna.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Harr|first1=Dan|title=Richard Lynch is Keepin’ It Country|url=http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/richard-lynch-keepin-country/|website=Music News Nashville|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>

==Achievements and awards==
* January 1, 2019, Lynch was inducted into the Ohio Country Music Hall of Fame
* Lynch was nominated as Best Male Country Artist by the Independent Country Music Association (2014) 
* Album "A Better Place" was named the Pure Country Album of the Year by the [[Academy of Western Artists]] (2015)<ref>{{cite web|title=2015 Winners and Finalists|url=http://awaawards.org/?page_id=329|website=Official website of the Academy of Western Artists|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
* The Richard Lynch Band was named the Traditional Country Band of the Year by the [[Josie Music Awards]] (2015)<ref>{{cite web|title=2015 Josie Awards Winners|url=http://www.josiemusicawards.com/2015-award-winners.html|website=The Josie Music Awards|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
* As a founder of Love Tattoo Foundation, Lynch was named the Humanitarian of the Year by the [[Josie Music Awards]] (2015)<ref>{{cite web|title=2015 Josie Awards Winners|url=http://www.josiemusicawards.com/2015-award-winners.html|website=The Josie Music Awards|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> 
* The Richard Lynch Band was named the Traditional Country Band of the Year by the [[Josie Music Awards]] (2015)<ref>{{cite web|title=2015 Josie Awards Winners|url=http://www.josiemusicawards.com/2015-award-winners.html|website=The Josie Music Awards|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
* Single "She's Got Me Drinkin' Again" was named the Song of the Year by CMG Global Radio (2015)<ref>{{cite web|title=Doug Briney Wins At 2015 CMG Global Awards|url=https://dougbriney.com/news|website=Official website of Doug Briney|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
* Single "A Better Place" was named No. 1 True Country Song by Roots Music Report (2016)<ref>{{cite web|title=The Roots Music Report's Top True Country Album Chart for the Year of 2016|url=https://rootsmusicreport.com/charts/view/album/sub_genre/true-country/yearly/2016|website=Roots Music Report|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> 
* Single "She's Got Me Drinkin' Again" (a duet with [[Billy Yates (singer)|Billy Yates]]) was nominated as Best “New Group/Duo” for the New Music Awards (2016)<ref>{{cite web|title=Billy Yates and Richard Lynch Are Nominated for 2016 New Music Award|url=http://www.billyyates.com/?section=news|website=Official website of Billy Yates|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
*2017 Richard Lynch receives seven nominations for the Annual [[Josie Music Awards]]. Traditional Male Country Artist, Traditional Country Male Vocalist, Video of The Year "We're American Proud, Traditional Country Song of The Year "Cut & Paste", Traditional Country Album of The Year "Mending Fences", Salute to America Song of The Year "We're American Proud", Traditional Country Entertainer of The Year. http://www.josiemusicawards.com/
